title: Is it a fact that if the U.S invaded Cuba in 1962 during the Cuban Missile Crisis, they would have confronted four times the 10,000 Soviet troops the CIA estimated there was at the time in Cuba? - Quora

response.answer_text: No it is not true. What the US invasion would have faced is a Soviet ground force what was already equipped with battlefield tactical nuclear weapons to be used in the defense of the medium and intermediate range nuclear armed missiles that the Soviet Union had installed in Cuba. 30+ plus years after the crisis and the end of the Cold War, Russian, Cuban, and American diplomats, soldiers, and historians met to fully discuss the crisis for the purposes of lessons learned. And the creation of a comprehensive historical record of the cold war confrontation. Unknown (in the West) until that time (the early 1990s), was the fact that the Soviet Union’s deployment of medium and intermediate range nuclear armed missiles to Cuba. Was not a impulsive, or ad hoc gesture of support, for an emerging communist ally of the Soviet Union. It was also most emphatically, not an impulsive gesture which the US, “caught just in time”, to allegedly, just avoid disaster. The Soviet Union sent 40+ thousand ground, air, and air defense forces to Cuba, before, and concurrent with, the deployment of medium and intermediate range nuclear armed missiles, to Cuba. Unknown to the US at the time, was the fact that the ground force was both experienced and well trained, in the defense of such semi-mobile missile installations. From similar deployments in Central and Eastern Europe, both in the Western Soviet Union, and in the territories of its Warsaw Pact allies. That training and experience was with battlefield tactical nuclear weapons; that they had been trained to use in defense of the nuclear armed medium and intermediate range missiles that were deployed, in the Western Soviet Union, and within the territories of Warsaw Pact allies. In short, a US invasion of Cuba seeking to overrun and neutralize the Soviet’s Cuba deployed semi-mobile missile bases. Would have been attacked by the Soviets in their defense against the American invasion, with battlefield nuclear weapons. Firing on the American invasion force. And contained fully within the territory of Cuba. From the history of that time it is recalled that President Kennedy declared (in public before the world, on television and radio), that as President and Commander-in-Chief of US Armed forces, he would regard an attack upon any other country in the Caribbean Basin, or the Western Hemisphere, by or from Cuba, to be regarded as; “…an attack by the Soviet Union upon the United States; requiring a retaliatory response by the United States…” Note: The Soviet Armed Forces’ use of battlefield nuclear weapons on the beaches (of Cuba) or less than 12 statute miles from the shoreline of Cuba (measured from low tide), would not meet President Kennedy’s publicly announced criteria, for a precipitate attack upon the Soviet Union, by the United States. As the very criteria that Kennedy had publicly stated, for such an attack. Would not appertain to the situation that the Soviets were capable of achieving. If the US had, executed an attempted invasion. Examined from the vantage point of nearly 60 years, it is clear that neither Kennedy, his Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara, or the Joint Chiefs, had the slightest notion of the situation that they were walking the country into.

No. Operation Anadyr [a river] was made up of the following elements: Four Motorized Rifle Regiments (without divisional structure): 302nd, 314th, 400th, and 496th.Two Anti-Aircraft Missile Divisions: the 10th and the 11th. The 10th had anti-aircraft guns, the 11th 144 S-75 SAMs.A Fighter Aviation Regiment, the 32nd Guards flying 40 MiG-21F-13, and 6 MiG-15UTI.The 51 Consolidated Missile Division consisting of the 79th Missile Regiment with 16 launchers and 24 R-14 (SS-5 Skean) missiles and the 181st Missile Regiment with 24 launchers and 36 R-12 (SS-4 Sandal) missiles. All carried nuclear warheads.The 134th Separate Aviation Squadron with 17 transport aircraft.The 437th Separate Helicopter Regiment with 33 Mi-4 (Hound) helicopters.The 561st and 584th Cruise Missile Regiments with 16 launchers for the FKR-1 cruise missile with a nuclear warhead. The 584th was also responsible for the 3 Luna (FROG-5) rocket detachments with a nuclear warhead as well (16 launchers and missiles).The 759th Mine and Torpedo Aviation Regiment with 33 Il-28 (Beagle) bombers. They had 6 nuclear warheads.The 5th Fleet with the 18th Naval Divison (2 cruisers (Project 68-bis (Sverdlov Class)), 4 destroyers ( 2Project 57-bis (Kanin Class) and 2 Project 56 (Kotlin Class)), and 12 missile boats (Project 183R (Komar Class)), and the 211th Submarine brigade (11 submarines: 7 Project 629 (Golf Class), one with three R-13 (SS-N-4 Sark) SLBMs, and 3 Project 641 (Foxtrot Class) submarines), 2 Project 310 floating bases, and six auxiliary vessels. Most surface vessels neer reached Cuba, the Komar Class missiles boats were an exception.Support units include three field hospitals (600 beds), a sanitation and anti-epidemic detachment, a base maintenance company, 7 storage depots, and a field bakery.The total number of Soviets troops, all branches, on Cuban soil numbered 50,874 and 3,000 civilian personnel attached to the Soviet Group of Forces in Cuba (official designation).
